p.s: The narrator predominantly distances himself from the protagonist in this scene because he is acting racist in terms of his first physical move.
The narrator is an overt third person narrator.
The first time he appears is in form of a comment using the telling mode of presentation (ll. 1-2) stating a question the reader might also have and therefore get him/her involved into the story.
As Delaney indirectly rejects Todd Sweet the dissapointmentdisappointment in his decision is presented in the change to the panoramic presentation (ll. 6-7).

When he realizes that the man he sees is Mexican it switches to the scenic presentation in order to express DelaneysDelaney's shock as it says ... something that struck him with the force of a blow ... (l. 16-17) but instantly changes to describing that the man was Mexican (l. 17), which shows that the narrator clearly distances himself.
It stays like that during the time the male protagonist prejudices come up and he connects more negative aspects with him like the interaction with Kyra.
In between the narrator comments on him finding more negative things about the Mexican reflecting his disbelievedisbelief (l. 24).
By using short sentences, parralelisms and description when conveying DelaneysDelaney's emotions (l. 31) the reader itn't able to sympathize with him because of the distance.
When he grappedgrabbed the mansman's wrist the narratorsnarrator's presence becomes clear again because of the telling mode (l. 42-43) which doesn't make the reader understand his actions at all.
After the americanAmerican realizes his fault and feels embaressedembarassed about it his thought are delivered in form of reported thought.
That influences the reader to be able to feelsfeel close to Delaney again and understand his emotions (l. 60-61).
